This pull request **introduces 1 alert** when merging c1a8808e8b6482ea2f8fb9c609b2c549786d8b58 into 7a30b8deea495bbc095fdd253cb81bae6655b02f - [view on LGTM.com](https://lgtm.com/projects/g/Azure/sonic-mgmt/rev/pr-e1439aa842eea1a3ed78a8d2aee90975b22ae03e)

* 1 for Variable defined multiple times
Thanks for the fix. But I'm not very clear why the second ```ARP request``` for IP ```192.168.0.2``` was sent? Why the delay is 5 seconds?

> Thanks for the fix. But I'm not very clear why the second `ARP request` for IP `192.168.0.2` was sent? Why the delay is 5 seconds?

@bingwang-ms From what I understand, second ARP request is an ARP probe, sent by DUT to verify that entry for 192.168.0.2 is still valid. 
Regarding 5 seconds delay, [ARP man page](https://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man7/arp.7.html) shows that default timeout before sending first probe is 5 seconds. I checked this on DUT:
```
cat /proc/sys/net/ipv4/neigh/Ethernet4/delay_first_probe_time
5
```

> > Thanks for the fix. But I'm not very clear why the second `ARP request` for IP `192.168.0.2` was sent? Why the delay is 5 seconds?
> 
> @bingwang-ms From what I understand, second ARP request is an ARP probe, sent by DUT to verify that entry for 192.168.0.2 is still valid.
> Regarding 5 seconds delay, [ARP man page](https://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man7/arp.7.html) shows that default timeout before sending first probe is 5 seconds. I checked this on DUT:
> 
> ```
> cat /proc/sys/net/ipv4/neigh/Ethernet4/delay_first_probe_time
> 5
> ```

Make sense to me. Thanks

comments.body: /azp run
Azure Pipelines successfully started running 1 pipeline(s).
@wangxin could you please take a look at https://github.com/Azure/sonic-mgmt/pull/3396 ? It addresses the issue with fixture imports

> @wangxin could you please take a look at #3396 ? It addresses the issue with fixture imports

#3396 imported more fixtures. We can discuss the details there. This PR has a limited scope of import. I am fine with get it in first and evaluation the rest with #3396.
Can you elaborate on how `rand_selected_dut` fixes the issue? It's not immediately obvious to me how it helps, since it still has the potential to choose the same device as `duthost`

> Can you elaborate on how `rand_selected_dut` fixes the issue? It's not immediately obvious to me how it helps, since it still has the potential to choose the same device as `duthost`

Sure. The class level autoused fixture ```prepareDut``` will load a config by ```swssconfig```  to set fdb aging time to ```60``` seconds.  This action is performed on one random selected dut.
```
def prepareDut(self, request, duthosts, rand_one_dut_hostname):
        duthost = duthosts[rand_one_dut_hostname]
        fdbAgingTime = request.config.getoption('--fdb_aging_time')
......
```
However, the test case is configured to run on a fixed dut (the upper ToR for a dualtor testbed). 
```
def testFdbMacExpire(self, request, tbinfo, duthost, ptfhost):
    ......
```
So, the DUT where the test case is running is possibly not the one we load config. That's why I change ```duthost``` to ```rand_selected_dut```. In other word, it's to ensure the test case will be running on the same device that swssconfig was loaded.
Thank you!

> As per the test plan, I believe these two test cases should be combined into one case - we also want to test the transition between standby and active, and back to standby to make sure the traffic goes to the tunnel/neighbor/tunnel accordingly.

@prsunny, could you please provide some of your thoughts here about how to organize those mac move testcases?

> > As per the test plan, I believe these two test cases should be combined into one case - we also want to test the transition between standby and active, and back to standby to make sure the traffic goes to the tunnel/neighbor/tunnel accordingly.
> 
> @prsunny, could you please provide some of your thoughts here about how to organize those mac move testcases?

Thats right. The test is expected as a sequence of operation to perform mac-move and verify. It is better to have it combined in one case. If we have it separated, then maintaining mac-move sequence would be harder. I believe, it will make the test simple as well.
@theasianpianist, updated, could you pls take another review?
I don't see the 'Simulate FDB ageout/flush' steps from the test plan, am I missing something?

> I don't see the 'Simulate FDB ageout/flush' steps from the test plan, am I missing something?

FDB will learn from heartbeats immediately after FDB flush/ageout, and stopping the `icmp_responder` will leave the ToRs in an unexpected state, discussed with @prsunny , let's leave those steps in `TODO`s.

> > I don't see the 'Simulate FDB ageout/flush' steps from the test plan, am I missing something?
> 
> FDB will learn from heartbeats immediately after FDB flush/ageout, and stopping the `icmp_responder` will leave the ToRs in an unexpected state, discussed with @prsunny , let's leave those steps in `TODO`s.

Agree with @lolyu that we cannot stop icmp responder. But discussed another method to use a different mac than the interface mac so that it won't get relearnt after fdbflush. @lolyu is trying out the change.
Thank you!

reviews.body: As per the test plan, I believe these two test cases should be combined into one case - we also want to test the transition between standby and active, and back to standby to make sure the traffic goes to the tunnel/neighbor/tunnel accordingly.
lgtm!

reviews.body:
It would be great if we can generalize the LogAnalyzer to support argument based log type grepping.
For example, here `analyze_sairedis` is added. But, in future this can grow to many different flags.
To prevent that, if we the caller can specify what files need to be analyzed, this would be useful for several other usecases.
Looking good. Some refactoring suggestions added. Suggest to test another unrelated test which uses log_analyzer, to make sure that there is no regression.
Lgtm, thanks for this useful enhancement!

This change removes colors from the logs for the different log levels (e.g. DEBUG is purple, INFO is green, ERROR is red, etc.). Is it possible to add the coloring back, since it makes it easier to pick out specific lines from the log?

> This change removes colors from the logs for the different log levels (e.g. DEBUG is purple, INFO is green, ERROR is red, etc.). Is it possible to add the coloring back, since it makes it easier to pick out specific lines from the log?

This should be a Pytest bug that `ColoredLevelFormatter` tries to find if there is `levelname` defined in the format string with this [regex](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/blob/9653a0e9f47ad2ae5135a974db52ddeb5bfcf5d9/src/_pytest/logging.py#L62), and the format string failed to match this regex because it has a precision defined.

comments.body: @vaibhavhd , @yxieca could you please point me to some HLD where requires changes for warm-reboot limit from default 30 to 0? Thank you in advance!

@SavchukRomanLv Warm-reboot data plane downtime was always expected to be 0s, with an exception of 1s expected downtime for Mellanox platforms.
The initial warm-reboot HLD also has a mention of this at the beginning:
https://github.com/Azure/SONiC/blob/master/doc/warm-reboot/SONiC_Warmboot.md#overview
`The goal of SONiC warm reboot is to be able restart and upgrade SONiC software without impacting the data plane.`

and here:
`Data plane should not be affected during the whole restore process. `:
https://github.com/Azure/SONiC/blob/master/doc/warm-reboot/SONiC_Warmboot.md#requirements-on-libsai-and-asic

Why not use "sonic_asic" object to do the work instead of checking for multi ASIC host, and evaluating the namespace every time. Add a BGP command API in the "sonic_asic.py" that takes of appending the "vtysh -n <asic>".

Hi, This is Sambath from Arista. Sorry I am little late on this. The test plan from https://github.com/Azure/sonic-mgmt/pull/3033/files as well as test cases does not seem to have any traffic validation. Would traffic validation be added in a future update to the test plan/test cases?

@skbarista Thank you for the review ! As we have mentioned in the test plan 'This test plan does not cover functioning of LAG as an IP/Layer3 endpoint as that is outside the scope of the code PR' we are not going to have traffic test cases in future too.

> @skbarista Thank you for the review ! As we have mentioned in the test plan 'This test plan does not cover functioning of LAG as an IP/Layer3 endpoint as that is outside the scope of the code PR' we are not going to have traffic test cases in future too.

Also, this test case will execute on a T2 topology, of which, LAG is a part. Many T1 test cases, when converted by the chassis subgroup, will cover this forwarding aspect.

We kept forwarding out of this because:
1. The code PR does not touch fwding and not even teamd
2.  Other forwarding tests check hashing and forwarding. So we avoided duplication
Thanks for the clarification @shubav @oxygen980
@wangxin comments from you and Arista have been addressed. If it looks fine, could you help get this merged, please?
I think the test will fail as the advanced-reboot script is not changed to support soft-reboot. Has this been tested so far, or we are waiting for the test to be performed?

reviews.body:
I think you will also need to do changes in advanced-reboot script. That is actually where the real IO test is located. For example you will need to add soft-reboot handler (similar to warm/fast that is present).
To start with, a reboot type needs to be added here:
https://github.com/Azure/sonic-mgmt/blob/master/ansible/roles/test/files/ptftests/advanced-reboot.py#L506

@wangxin @jleveque @yaxia could you please take a look?
Thank you!

> LGTM. Please improve it with LAG and T1 support in the future. For the multiple monitoring port case, only `rx` direction is covered. It would be better to cover the other scenarios like:
> 
> * `tx` + `tx`
> * `tx` + `rx`
> * `both` + `both`
> * `both` + `rx`
> * `both` + `tx`

@wangxin each session only allows 1 direction, either 'rx', 'tx' or 'both'. To cover scenarios like 'rx + tx' we will need to create 2 separate sessions. I will add those in the future.

In regards to multiple source ports per 1 session, I'm working on using parametrization based on direction and source ports count.
Thanks @vcheketx!

latestReviews.body:
LGTM. Please improve it with LAG and T1 support in the future. For the multiple monitoring port case, only `rx` direction is covered. It would be better to cover the other scenarios like:
* `tx` + `tx`
* `tx` + `rx`
* `both` + `both`
* `both` + `rx`
* `both` + `tx`

reviews.body:
LGTM. Please improve it with LAG and T1 support in the future. For the multiple monitoring port case, only `rx` direction is covered. It would be better to cover the other scenarios like:
* `tx` + `tx`
* `tx` + `rx`

This pull request **introduces 5 alerts** when merging e2c17bab6d5cdc7da7329c9f4c710a8e56c2cd82 into a2a435c4bbbcf96241b61f5084407ff9e4b5960f - [view on LGTM.com](https://lgtm.com/projects/g/Azure/sonic-mgmt/rev/pr-7824c9e3c3dba061bc51455f7febbcbfeb3497e2)

**new alerts:**

* 5 for Result of integer division may be truncated
can you fix LGTM ?

> can you fix LGTM ?

Have fixed most LGTM errors, the remaining one on result of integer division may be truncated is fine from the test logic perspective and can be ignored?

it can't be fix ?
